lines.text: You've suffered enough. You can be King, or you can be free. Which is it?
Take me to where the Crown of France is to be found.
[Last lines]
He was a brave man. France will always need brave men.
And brave women to remind them of their duty. God save France!

[as Louis]
I became King on my fifth birthday. By my sixth I learned not to offer encouragement. Sooner or later everyone comes to me.

[as Louis]
A king fears tradition more than he does assassination. There is a chance for me to escape assassination but not tradition. It's one of the unfortunate things connected with being King.

[Seeing nine soldiers matched against him and his three musketeer friends]
Is the King being frugal? Only nine men?
And ninety more outside!

[With bravado]
Flatterer!
Bravery is only great when there is no chance.
There is one law in life, my brother, that not even a king can escape... the law of retribution!

[Seeing that D'Artagnan is wouded]
Are you hurt?
Always remember to lick your wounds after the battle.

[as Louis in the torture chamber]
I know how well you love complete power, Fouquet, but you will never know complete power until you are obeyed in a place like this.
How could your brother be such a monster?

[after Fouquet has just killed his wife]
Where are you going?
After a murderer!

[With contempt]
Let me congradulate you, my friend, but then you always had the most annoying habit of bringing about the things you wish to bring about. Most amusing comedy - worthy of so great a playwright!
As a fellow playwright you understand how narrow the line dividing comedy and tragedy.
Quite right, and I'm afraid His Majesty's executioner will provide the tragedy when this charming little comedy is finished.
His Majesty's executioner could provide the tragedy before the comedy is finished.
I have a better cure for madness than any doctor.

[as Louis]
So they don't like the salt tax? DOUBLE IT!
Thank you my friend. I appreciate everything you've done for me.
I hope France will appreciate everything you've done for her.

[Dying]
Congradulations, my son. Now you will be the greatest swordsman in France.

[In his cell]
I hope you bring me liberty.
More than liberty, I bring you opportunity.
All I need is opportunity.
We're through with running!
